The convolutions $\otimes$ in {Eq.~}\eqref{eq:nlobk} denote integration over the transverse coordinate $z$ (in $K_1^\text{BC}$) or $z$ and $z'$ (in $K_2$ and $K_f$). We use the notation $X^2=(x-z)^2$, $X'^2=(x-z')^2$, $Y=(y-z)^2$ and $Y'=(y-z')^2$. 

Because every trace is proportional to ${N_\mathrm{c}}$, in the large-${N_\mathrm{c}}$ limit the terms with traces of more than two Wilson lines can be neglected. The large-${N_\mathrm{c}}$ limit also implies the mean-field limit, where the correlators of products of traces factorize into products of the two-point function $S(r)$. This mean-field limit closes the equation: the rapidity derivative of the dipole operator $S(r)$ can be computed in terms of $S(r)$ only. 
At finite ${N_\mathrm{c}}$, correlators of more than two Wilson lines are needed which, in principle, have their own evolution equations. In that case one should solve an infinite hierarchy of coupled evolution equations, or equivalently the JIMWLK~\cite{JalilianMarian:1996xn,JalilianMarian:1997jx, JalilianMarian:1997gr,Iancu:2001md, Ferreiro:2001qy, Iancu:2001ad, Iancu:2000hn} equation at NLO accuracy~\cite{Balitsky:2013fea,Kovner:2013ona}. This would be numerically demanding, and a much more practical approach could be to use e.g. the so called Gaussian approximation (see e.g. {Ref.~}\cite{Dominguez:2011wm}) to express the higher-point functions in terms of the dipole operator only. As the effect of the finite-${N_\mathrm{c}}$ corrections to the leading order BK equation is known to be much smaller than $\sim 1/{N_\mathrm{c}}^2\approx 10\%$ (which would be a naive expectation from the $1/{N_\mathrm{c}}$ expansion)~\cite{Kovchegov:2008mk}, we take the large-${N_\mathrm{c}}$ limit in this work. 

One of the NLO corrections is the running of the QCD coupling ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}$. The term involving the renormalization scale $\mu^2$ in {Eq.~}\eqref{eq:orig_k1} should be absorbed into the running of ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}$. What other terms are included in the scale-dependent coupling is a scheme choice.  We adopt the choice derived in Ref.~\cite{Balitsky:2006wa} and replace all terms in $K_1^\text{BC}$ proportional to the beta function coefficient $\beta=\frac{11}{3}{N_\mathrm{c}} - \frac{2}{3}{n_\mathrm{f}}$ (with ${n_\mathrm{f}}=3$ in this work) by the so called Balitsky running coupling.
This  prescription is used here because we want to resum all large logarithms, and the Balitsky running coupling resums ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}} \beta$ contributions, and in particular the logarithm $\sim \beta \ln X^2/Y^2$ from $K_1^\text{BC}$.

The Balitsky prescription has been successfully used in phenomenological applications to include running coupling effects in the leading order BK equation. For the other terms we choose to evaluate ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}$ at the scale given by the size of the parent dipole $r$, as it is the only available external scale. Notice also that for the ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}^2$ terms the difference between the scale choices for the coupling is formally a higher-order ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}^3$ correction. The kernel $K_1$ can now be written as
\begin{widetext}
prevtext:
The kernels and Wilson line operators derived in~\cite{Balitsky:2008zza} are
\begin{widetext}
text:
\begin{align}
\label{eq:orig_k1}
K^\textnormal{BC}_1 &= \frac{r^2}{X^2Y^2} \left[ 1+\frac{{\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}{N_\mathrm{c}} }{4\pi} \left(  \frac{\beta}{{N_\mathrm{c}}} \ln r^2\mu^2 - \frac{\beta}{{N_\mathrm{c}}} \frac{X^2-Y^2}{r^2} \ln \frac{X^2}{Y^2} + \frac{67}{9} - \frac{\pi^2}{3} - \frac{10}{9} \frac{{n_\mathrm{f}}}{{N_\mathrm{c}}} - 2\ln \frac{X^2}{r^2} \ln \frac{Y^2}{r^2} \right) \right]
\\
D_1 &= \frac{1}{{N_\mathrm{c}}} {\, \mathrm{Tr} \, } (U_x U^\dagger_z) \frac{1}{{N_\mathrm{c}}} {\, \mathrm{Tr} \, }(U_z U^\dagger_y) - \frac{1}{{N_\mathrm{c}}} {\, \mathrm{Tr} \, } (U_x U^\dagger_y)  \\
K_2 &= -\frac{2}{(z-z')^4} + \left[ \frac{X^2 Y'^2 + X'^2Y^2 - 4r^2(z-z')^2}{(z-z')^4(X^2Y'^2 - X'^2Y^2)} + \frac{r^4}{X^2Y'^2(X^2Y'^2 - X'^2Y^2)} + \frac{r^2}{X^2Y'^2(z-z')^2} \right]\\
& \quad  \times  \ln \frac{X^2Y'^2}{X'^2Y^2} \nonumber
\\
D_2 &= \frac{1}{{N_\mathrm{c}}} {\, \mathrm{Tr} \, } (U_x U^\dagger_z) \frac{1}{{N_\mathrm{c}}}  {\, \mathrm{Tr} \, } (U_z U^\dagger_{z\smash{'}}) \frac{1}{{N_\mathrm{c}}} {\, \mathrm{Tr} \, } (U_{z\smash{'}}U^\dagger_y)  - \frac{1}{{N_\mathrm{c}}} {\, \mathrm{Tr} \, } (U_x U^\dagger_z ) \frac{1}{{N_\mathrm{c}}}  {\, \mathrm{Tr} \, } (U_z U^\dagger_y) 
\\ \nonumber
& \quad - \frac{1}{{N_\mathrm{c}}^3} {\, \mathrm{Tr} \, } (U_x U^\dagger_z U_{z\smash{'}} U^\dagger_y U_z U^\dagger_{z\smash{'}}) + \frac{1}{{N_\mathrm{c}}^3} {\, \mathrm{Tr} \, } (U_x U^\dagger_y) \\
 K_f &= \frac{2}{(z-z')^4}  
	- \frac{X'^2Y^2 + Y'^2 X^2 - r^2 (z-z')^2}{(z-z')^4(X^2Y'^2 - X'^2Y^2)} \ln \frac{X^2Y'^2}{X'^2Y^2} \\
D_f &= \frac{1}{{N_\mathrm{c}}} {\, \mathrm{Tr} \, } (U_y U^\dagger_z) \left( \frac{1}{{N_\mathrm{c}}} {\, \mathrm{Tr} \, } (U_x U^\dagger_{z\smash{'}}) - \frac{1}{{N_\mathrm{c}}} {\, \mathrm{Tr} \, } (U_x U^\dagger_z)\right) + \frac{1}{{N_\mathrm{c}}^4} {\, \mathrm{Tr} \, } (U_xU^\dagger_y){\, \mathrm{Tr} \, }( U_z U^\dagger_{z\smash{'}}) 
\\ \nonumber
	&\quad - \frac{1}{{N_\mathrm{c}}^3} {\, \mathrm{Tr} \, }( U_x U^\dagger_y U_z U^\dagger_{z\smash{'}}) - \frac{1}{{N_\mathrm{c}}^3} {\, \mathrm{Tr} \, } (U_x U^\dagger_{z\smash{'}} U_z U^\dagger_y)  + \frac{1}{{N_\mathrm{c}}^3} {\, \mathrm{Tr} \, } (U_xU^\dagger_y)
\end{align}

The convolutions $\otimes$ in {Eq.~}\eqref{eq:nlobk} denote integration over the transverse coordinate $z$ (in $K_1^\text{BC}$) or $z$ and $z'$ (in $K_2$ and $K_f$). We use the notation $X^2=(x-z)^2$, $X'^2=(x-z')^2$, $Y=(y-z)^2$ and $Y'=(y-z')^2$. 

Because every trace is proportional to ${N_\mathrm{c}}$, in the large-${N_\mathrm{c}}$ limit the terms with traces of more than two Wilson lines can be neglected. The large-${N_\mathrm{c}}$ limit also implies the mean-field limit, where the correlators of products of traces factorize into products of the two-point function $S(r)$. This mean-field limit closes the equation: the rapidity derivative of the dipole operator $S(r)$ can be computed in terms of $S(r)$ only. 
At finite ${N_\mathrm{c}}$, correlators of more than two Wilson lines are needed which, in principle, have their own evolution equations. In that case one should solve an infinite hierarchy of coupled evolution equations, or equivalently the JIMWLK~\cite{JalilianMarian:1996xn,JalilianMarian:1997jx, JalilianMarian:1997gr,Iancu:2001md, Ferreiro:2001qy, Iancu:2001ad, Iancu:2000hn} equation at NLO accuracy~\cite{Balitsky:2013fea,Kovner:2013ona}. This would be numerically demanding, and a much more practical approach could be to use e.g. the so called Gaussian approximation (see e.g. {Ref.~}\cite{Dominguez:2011wm}) to express the higher-point functions in terms of the dipole operator only. As the effect of the finite-${N_\mathrm{c}}$ corrections to the leading order BK equation is known to be much smaller than $\sim 1/{N_\mathrm{c}}^2\approx 10\%$ (which would be a naive expectation from the $1/{N_\mathrm{c}}$ expansion)~\cite{Kovchegov:2008mk}, we take the large-${N_\mathrm{c}}$ limit in this work. 

One of the NLO corrections is the running of the QCD coupling ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}$. The term involving the renormalization scale $\mu^2$ in {Eq.~}\eqref{eq:orig_k1} should be absorbed into the running of ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}$. What other terms are included in the scale-dependent coupling is a scheme choice.  We adopt the choice derived in Ref.~\cite{Balitsky:2006wa} and replace all terms in $K_1^\text{BC}$ proportional to the beta function coefficient $\beta=\frac{11}{3}{N_\mathrm{c}} - \frac{2}{3}{n_\mathrm{f}}$ (with ${n_\mathrm{f}}=3$ in this work) by the so called Balitsky running coupling.
This  prescription is used here because we want to resum all large logarithms, and the Balitsky running coupling resums ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}} \beta$ contributions, and in particular the logarithm $\sim \beta \ln X^2/Y^2$ from $K_1^\text{BC}$.

The Balitsky prescription has been successfully used in phenomenological applications to include running coupling effects in the leading order BK equation. For the other terms we choose to evaluate ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}$ at the scale given by the size of the parent dipole $r$, as it is the only available external scale. Notice also that for the ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}^2$ terms the difference between the scale choices for the coupling is formally a higher-order ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}^3$ correction. The kernel $K_1$ can now be written as

nexttext:
The parameters $c$ and $\mu_0$ control the infrared behavior of the coupling constant, and here we take $\mu_0/{\Lambda_{\mathrm{QCD}}}=2.5$ and $c=0.2$, which freezes the coupling to $\approx 0.76$ in the infrared.
Note the constant factor $4e^{-2\gamma_\mathrm{E}}\approx 1.26$ in the identification 
$k^2 \sim 4e^{-2\gamma_{\mathrm{E}}} /r^2$, which is taken from the explicit
Fourier transform of the kernel calculated analytically in {Refs.~}\cite{Gardi:2006rp,Kovchegov:2006vj} and confirmed numerically in {Ref.~}\cite{Lappi:2012vw}. In the leading order fits to the deep inelastic scattering data the scale at which the coupling is evaluated is taken as a fit parameter by identifying $k^2 \sim 4C^2/r^2$. These fits require $C^2\sim 4 \dots 20$ in order to get a slow enough evolution speed~\cite{Albacete:2010sy}. 
In this work we do not seek parametrizations that give a best fit to the DIS data, and use the theoretically motivated value $C^2=e^{-2\gamma_\mathrm{E}}$. 


The NLO BK equation was first solved in {Ref.~}\cite{Lappi:2015fma} where it was shown that the equation is unstable. In particular, depending on the initial condition the dipole amplitude $N(r)=1-S(r)$ may decrease or even become negative when rapidity increases, which is unphysical as it would correspond to a decrease of the  unintegrated gluon distribution when decreasing the momentum fraction $x$. The origin of this problematic behavior was traced back to the double logarithmic term $\sim \ln \frac{X^2}{r^2} \ln \frac{Y^2}{r^2}$ in the kernel $K_1$. To fix this problem, a resummation of large logarithmic corrections is needed.





\section{Resumming large logarithms}
\label{sec:resum}
There are two sources of large logarithmic corrections to the BK equation that must be resummed to all orders. First, as shown in {Ref.~}\cite{Iancu:2015vea}, the successive gluon emissions that are strongly ordered in both transverse and longitudinal momenta
generate a large double logarithmic contribution $\sim \ln X^2/r^2 \ln Y^2/r^2$ to the NLO BK equation. 
These contributions are resummed in {Ref.~}\cite{Iancu:2015vea} to all orders in ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}} \ln X^2/r^2 \ln Y^2/r^2$, and the effect of the resummation is to remove the double logarithmic term from the kernel $K_1$, and multiply it by an oscillatory factor

\end{widetext}

The strong coupling constant ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}$ at the given distance scale $r$ is evaluated as

nexttext:
The double logarithm here is $x=\sqrt{\ln X^2/r^2 \ln Y^2/r^2}$, and ${\bar{\alpha}_{\mathrm{s}}} = {\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}} {N_\mathrm{c}}/\pi$. If $\ln X^2/r^2 \ln Y^2/r^2<0$, then an absolute value is used and the Bessel function is changed to $J_1 \to I_1$, see {Ref.~}\cite{Iancu:2015vea}.

In addition to the kernel of the evolution equation, also the initial condition for the BK evolution must be resummed. For this the dipole amplitude is parametrized as
prevtext:
The parameters $c$ and $\mu_0$ control the infrared behavior of the coupling constant, and here we take $\mu_0/{\Lambda_{\mathrm{QCD}}}=2.5$ and $c=0.2$, which freezes the coupling to $\approx 0.76$ in the infrared.
Note the constant factor $4e^{-2\gamma_\mathrm{E}}\approx 1.26$ in the identification 
$k^2 \sim 4e^{-2\gamma_{\mathrm{E}}} /r^2$, which is taken from the explicit
Fourier transform of the kernel calculated analytically in {Refs.~}\cite{Gardi:2006rp,Kovchegov:2006vj} and confirmed numerically in {Ref.~}\cite{Lappi:2012vw}. In the leading order fits to the deep inelastic scattering data the scale at which the coupling is evaluated is taken as a fit parameter by identifying $k^2 \sim 4C^2/r^2$. These fits require $C^2\sim 4 \dots 20$ in order to get a slow enough evolution speed~\cite{Albacete:2010sy}. 
In this work we do not seek parametrizations that give a best fit to the DIS data, and use the theoretically motivated value $C^2=e^{-2\gamma_\mathrm{E}}$. 


The NLO BK equation was first solved in {Ref.~}\cite{Lappi:2015fma} where it was shown that the equation is unstable. In particular, depending on the initial condition the dipole amplitude $N(r)=1-S(r)$ may decrease or even become negative when rapidity increases, which is unphysical as it would correspond to a decrease of the  unintegrated gluon distribution when decreasing the momentum fraction $x$. The origin of this problematic behavior was traced back to the double logarithmic term $\sim \ln \frac{X^2}{r^2} \ln \frac{Y^2}{r^2}$ in the kernel $K_1$. To fix this problem, a resummation of large logarithmic corrections is needed.





\section{Resumming large logarithms}
\label{sec:resum}

Note that we choose to use the parent dipole running coupling in $K_\text{sub}$ as we want it to cancel the corresponding contribution originating from the kernel $K_2$ (the $M_\text{STL}$ part) which uses the same parent dipole prescription. 
Thus the subtraction term $K_\text{sub}$ does not precisely cancel the ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}^2$ term of the expansion of $K_\text{STL}$ times the full Balitsky running coupling. Because the difference between the running coupling schemes is of higher order in ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}$, $K_\text{sub}$ does, however, cancel the contribution from the ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}^2$ term in $K_\text{STL}$ to the order ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}^2$, which is enough for the purpose of this work.

which is convoluted with the dipole part $D_1$. This corresponds to the contribution of the resummed NLO equation of~\cite{Iancu:2015joa} on top of the usual running coupling LO equation. The fixed order ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}^2$ contribution consists of the additional contribution of the kernels $K_\text{sub}$, $K_1^\text{fin}$, $K_2$ and $K_f$. We find that the fixed order NLO terms give a very small positive contribution to the evolution speed at small dipoles, and the resummed  large logarithms significantly slow down the evolution speed.
Note that while $K_2$ and $K_\text{sub}$ separately have a large single logarithmic contribution at small parent dipoles, this cancels in the total fixed order ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}^2$ term (``other ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}^2$'' in {Fig.~}\ref{fig:dndy_terms}).
 At larger dipoles $r\sim 1/{Q_\mathrm{s}}$ the resummation and the other NLO contributions are numerically equally important and mostly cancel each other, and the total evolution speed is close to the evolution of speed of the leading order BK equation in this regime.

When the calculation is done at larger saturation scales by increasing the value of ${Q_\mathrm{s,0}}$, the relative importance of fixed order ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}^2$ terms compared to the resummation around $r \sim 1/{Q_\mathrm{s}}$ is decreased. The same effect is observed when the contributions are studied after $10$ units of rapidity evolution in {Fig.~}\ref{fig:dndy_terms_y_10}. This corressponds to saturation scales ${Q_\mathrm{s}}/{\Lambda_{\mathrm{QCD}}} \approx 19$ and ${Q_\mathrm{s}}/{\Lambda_{\mathrm{QCD}}} \approx 66$ for ${Q_\mathrm{s,0}}/{\Lambda_{\mathrm{QCD}}}=2$ and ${Q_\mathrm{s,0}}/{\Lambda_{\mathrm{QCD}}}=10$, respectively.  The oscillations visible at $y=0$, that originate from the resummation of the initial condition, are washed out in the evolution.  It can also be seen that the MV model initial condition is closer to the asymptotic solution of the resummed NLO BK equation than it is for the leading order equation, as $\partial_y N/N$ is roughly constant in a much larger range of parent dipole sizes.
 
Let us  then demonstrate the importance of the fixed order ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}^2$ contributions at $r\sim 1/{Q_\mathrm{s}}$ relative to the resummation effects in more detail.  In {Fig.~}\ref{fig:dndy_as_resum_ratio} we show the contribution to the rapidity derivative of the dipole amplitude, $\partial_y N(r)$, originating from the ${\alpha_{\mathrm{s}}}^2$ terms, normalized by the contribution of the resummation terms.
